result.rationale: This species is endemic to Lake Malawi where it is only known from a single small island. It meets the area requirements under criterion B for Critically Endangered and it is known from one location based on the threat of collection (B1a). However, future declines in habitat quality or population size are possible but uncertain. The effects of aquarium trade and sedimentation on this species are unknown and it is, therefore, listed as Near Threatened.
result.geographicrange: This species is endemic to Lake Malawi and only known from Mbenji Island.
result.population: Pseudotropheus galanos is a common cichlid around Mbenji Island.
result.habitat: This species occurs mainly in the upper regions of the sediment-free rocky habitat. It lives among medium-sized and large rocks in less than 10 m depth. Females, juveniles and non territorial adult males occur in groups. Males are territorial and defend a spawning site inside a cave in the rocky habitat, feeding feed from the aufwuchs in their territories and upon plankton in the water column above their territories. All non territorial individuals feed on plankton in the water column and mouth-brooding females hide between rocks. Maximum total length is approximately 11 cm.
result.threats: Sedimentation of the near shore rocky habitat and extraction by the ornamental fish trade are potential threats.
result.conservationmeasures: No information is available on conservation actions for this species.
result.usetrade: It is regularly collected by the ornamental fish trade where it is known as "Red Top Brevis". It is of no importance to subsistence fishermen.
